conclusion: To determine whether the distance fallen during the 0 to 10 seconds interval is greater than or less than 100 meters, we need to analyze the area under the velocity-time graph for that interval. The area under the v-t graph represents the displacement (or distance fallen in this case).
From the graph, we can see that the velocity increases from 0 m/s at t = 0 s to approximately 20 m/s at t = 10 s.
The shape of the curve between t = 0 s and t = 10 s appears to be a smooth curve, not a straight line.

premise: If the velocity had increased linearly from 0 m/s to 20 m/s over 10 seconds, the graph would form a right triangle.
conclusion: The area of this triangle would be: Area = 1/2 × base × height = 1/2 × 10 s × 20 m/s = 100 m

premise: The actual curve is not a straight line but a curve that rises more gradually initially and then steepens towards the end.
conclusion: Since the actual curve is concave up (it rises more slowly at first and then faster), the area under the curve will be less than the area of the triangle formed by a straight line.

premise: Since the actual curve is concave up (it rises more slowly at first and then faster), the area under the curve will be less than the area of the triangle formed by a straight line.
conclusion: The distance fallen will be less than 100 meters.
